2.text: Are sharks killers like in the movies

responses.3: Sometimes they can kill for pleasure

2.answer: No, they're not killers. That's not because they're shown acting like killers that this is true. In fact sharks are rarely hunting because they're not eating much. Also, to them human flesh is not a very tasty meal. Finally, this notion of 'killer' is really human and shouldn't be applied to shark's behaviors.

responses.1: A movement made by associations to save and protect sharks
responses.3: A specific behavior which occurs only when sharks are eating

3.answer: Shark finning is the act of removing fins from sharks and discarding the rest of the shark back into the ocean. This act is prohibited in many countries. The sharks are often still alive when discarded, but without their fins. Unable to swim effectively, they sink to the bottom of the ocean and die of suffocation or are eaten by other predators.

4.text: Can we observe great white sharks in captivity
4.answer: It seems that they're incapable to survive in captivity. During the past some tries have been made such as the one in 2016 at Okinawa island in the south of Japan, Churaumi aquarium tried to conserve a male victim of unfortunate fishing. He died 3 days after being captured. Studies showed that he refused to eat. In fact great white sharks travel hundreds of kilometers, we can't image the size of the aquarium to contain such space. Moreover, they can develop psychological diseases being separated from their natural environment.

5.text: Why can't we see skeleton of sharks

responses.2: It's very difficult to get them because they're drowning deeply to the abysses

5.answer: Sharks have cartilage skeleton, they don't have bones covering their body like a fish you can buy at the supermarket. As so, when they die, everything can be eaten by their relatives into the ocean.

blue_shark.name: Blue shark
blue_shark.description: Slender shark with an iridescent blue coloration. Found worldwide in temperate and tropical oceanic waters, often in large aggregations segregated by size and sex, and feeds mostly on fish and squid. Most heavily fished shark in the world.
blue_shark.distribution: The blue shark inhabits all the oceans and seas of the world. This shark is pelagic but may occasionally stay close to the continental belt. Young blue sharks are sometimes observed near the coast.

bronze_whale_shark.name: Bronze whale shark
bronze_whale_shark.description: The copper shark is a species of shark in the family Carcharhinidae, and the only member of its genus found at latitudes corresponding to a temperate climate.
bronze_whale_shark.distribution: The copper shark is the only member of its genus found widely in temperate rather than tropical waters.

bull_shark.name: Bull shark
bull_shark.description: A large, stocky shark. Lives worldwide in tropical and subtropical seas. One of the few sharks capable of swimming in freshwater. Active in turbid waters along coasts and upstream rivers. Feeds mainly on fish and seabirds. Responsible for most bites.
bull_shark.distribution: The bull shark is found on the coasts of all the tropical and subtropical seas of the world. It is common in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific, but much rarer in the Red Sea. In the Pacific Ocean, it is found from Baja California to the Equator. It is both coastal and semi-pelagic depending on the regions and life stages, fond of depths between the surface and up to potentially more than 250 meters, but generally around 30m. It particularly appreciates muddy or highly turbid water, for example at the mouth of a river after a tropical cyclone.

dusty_shark.name: Dusty shark
dusty_shark.description: The sand shark is a fairly massive shark that can reach 4 m and weigh more than 300 kg, but most individuals observed measure around 2.5 m and weigh 200 kg. It is a species with large green/yellow eyes and can be confused with the bulldog shark. As its name suggests, it has a dark back, dark gray in juveniles and lighter gray in adults.
dusty_shark.distribution: It is present in the three large oceans (Indian, Atlantic and Pacific) but prefers warm waters (above 25 degrees) as well as brackish. This species is also present in the Mediterranean, more particularly in the Eastern Mediterranean.

gray_nurse_shark.name: Gray nurse shark
gray_nurse_shark.description: The sand tiger shark, also known as the gray nurse shark, is a slow-moving coastal predator distinguished by its flattened, conical snout and spiked, protruding teeth similar to the tiger shark. It has small eyes and light brown skin that resembles sand, helping the shark blend into its surroundings when looked at from above.
gray_nurse_shark.distribution: The gray nurse shark lives off the coasts of Australia, the United States and South Africa, and more widely in the Atlantic Ocean, the Indian Ocean, the Pacific Ocean, the Red Sea and the Mediterranean (specifically the Western Mediterranean). It is a migrant, and it is found in many temperate zones.

hammerhead_shark.name: Great Hammerhead shark
hammerhead_shark.description: The great hammerhead shark is the largest of all hammerhead species, reaching a maximum known length of 20 feet (6.1 m) and weight of 991 pounds (450 kg). The species is distinguished from other hammerheads by its nearly straight hammer-shaped head (cephalofoil) that has a prominent indentation in the middle.
hammerhead_shark.distribution: It is a cosmopolitan shark, widely distributed in temperate, tropical and subtropical seas around the world. It is generally found in depths ranging from 0 to 200 m. It is more easily observed in the Gulf of Guinea during the cold season (December to May) and especially towards Senegal. On the contrary, it migrates north in summer.

tiger_shark.name: Tiger shark
tiger_shark.description: The tiger shark gets its name from the characteristic vertical bars that cover the sides of its body. Though these bars fade slightly as individuals reach adulthood, they are very noticeable in juveniles and at least party visible throughout the lifetime. Reaching lengths of at least 18 feet (5.5 m) and 2000 pounds (nearly a metric tonne), the tiger shark is the fourth largest shark and second largest predatory shark, behind only the great white.
tiger_shark.distribution: Its habitat is coastal and pelagic. It is present in all tropical and subtropical seas, with a preference for waters with high turbidity, estuaries, lagoons, from the surface to - 350 meters. It is very present in the Caribbean, in the Indian Ocean and throughout the Pacific. It is solitary and resident or semi-resident around certain volcanic islands, however sometimes evolving in small groups. Although not oceanic, it happens to operate long crossings between islands, especially in the Pacific. Its activity is mainly nocturnal. During the day, it joins the deep waters and only comes out when night falls to hunt.

whale_shark.name: Whale shark
whale_shark.description: The largest fish in the world is the graceful, harmless whale shark. Though they reach the size of a school bus, whale sharks eat tiny plankton and fish eggs, which they filter feed as they swim slowly along with their giant mouths wide open. They are one of only three species of filter feeding sharks.
whale_shark.distribution: The whale shark is found in tropical and temperate to warm waters of the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans. In winter, young whale sharks come to feed on plankton in the nutrient-rich waters of the Gulf of Tadjourah, off the coast of Djibouti. The whale shark lives in a band around the equator up to 30° north latitude and 35° south latitude. It is an essentially pelagic species living offshore in very deep water.

white_shark.name: Great White shark
white_shark.description: Largest of the predatory sharks, most iconic due to media. Found worldwide with the widest range of any shark and can be found in most oceans. Breaches up to 10 ft (3 m) into the air. Investigates humans, involved in shark bites.
white_shark.distribution: The habitat of the great white shark is mainly coastal in temperate waters, but it has also been observed in epipelagic areas in the ocean. It is a shallow water lover, however one specimen was caught on a 1280m long line.

basking_shark.name: Basking shark
basking_shark.description: The basking shark is the second largest fish in the world, and like the largest fish (the whale shark) and the largest animal (the great whales), basking sharks are filter feeders that eat tiny, planktonic prey. Reaching lengths of 40 feet (12 m) and resembling predatory sharks in appearance, the basking shark can give an intimidating impression, but they are quite harmless. They spend most of their time near the surface, swimming with their extraordinarily large mouths open, filtering out their preferred prey, but they may also make deeper, feeding dives.
basking_shark.distribution: The Peregrine prefers areas where zooplankton are concentrated. These are fronts where water masses meet or headlands and areas of strong tides around islands and in bays. A 2008 study shows that this shark may also use habitats deeper than 1,000 m.

spiny_dogfish.name: Spiny dogfish
spiny_dogfish.description: The spiny dogfish may go by many names, including piked dogfish, rock salmon and spiky dog, but only one truly represents this shark’s unique defense strategy. Using sharp, venomous spines in the front of each dorsal fin, the spiny dogfish is a small but mighty predator that isn’t afraid to take a jab at passing fish. They are considered one of the most abundant living shark species in the ocean, but are harmless to humans.
spiny_dogfish.distribution: Dogfish are found between the cool, shallow waters of temperate and subarctic zones of the northern hemisphere, in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans1. It lives at depths of 10 to 200 m, but has already been observed at 960 m depth. It is a seasonally migrating fish, living in waters whose temperature fluctuates between 5 and 16°C and which reproduces offshore.

shortfin_mako_shark.name: Shortfin mako shark
shortfin_mako_shark.description: The fastest shark of all, reaching up to 40 mph. Found worldwide in temperate and tropical seas. Brilliant blue coloration. Highly prized for its meat and fins.
shortfin_mako_shark.distribution: Pelagic and sometimes coastal in tropical and temperate waters. Evolves from the surface to 740 meters deep.

grey_shark.name: Grey shark
grey_shark.description: Caution, two species of sharks are called “grey sharks”: Carcharhinus amblyrhynchos but also Carcharhinus plumbeus. For this reason, it is preferable to specify “Grey reef shark” for Carcharhinus amblyrhynchos. The Gray Reef Shark has a moderately slender body and a long, broad, blunt snout. The eyes are almost circular.
grey_shark.distribution: The gray reef shark is native to the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean. In the Indian Ocean, it is found from South Africa to India, passing through Madagascar and the nearby islands, the Red Sea and the Maldives. In the Pacific Ocean, it lives from southern China to northern Australia and New Zealand through the Gulf of Thailand, the Philippines and Indonesia. This species has also been observed off many Pacific islands.

thresher_shark.name: Thresher shark
thresher_shark.description: The pelagic thresher shark is one of three thresher sharks, all three known for their extremely long tails. Adult pelagic threshers’ tails are longer than the rest of the body. Scientists believe that they are highly migratory, but there have not been sufficient tagging studies to confirm that suspicion. Little is known about the ecology of pelagic thresher sharks, as they are difficult to study in their natural habitat (the open ocean).
thresher_shark.distribution: The distribution of the common thresher shark encompasses all tropical and cold temperate waters.

porbeagle.name: Porbeagle
porbeagle.description: The porbeagle shark is a wide-ranging shark that’s recognized by its conical snout, white underbelly and dark gray top. Scholars have proposed that the porbeagle shark’s name originates from the combination of “porpoise” and “beagle” – referencing the shark’s rounded body and dogged hunting methods.
porbeagle.distribution: This shark frequents the coast and the epipelagic zone (0 to 370 m) is absent from equatorial waters; it prefers cold waters below 18°C. Mainly present in the North Atlantic, it is also found in Australia, Brazil and Chile.

smalltooth_sand_tiger.name: Smalltooth sand tiger
smalltooth_sand_tiger.description: The fierce shark is a species of shark in the family Odontaspididae, which lives up to 1,000 meters deep and can reach five meters in length. He is called 'fierce' because of his prominent and threatening teeth, but does not seem aggressive towards humans - whom he is unlikely to meet anyway given his usual depth.
smalltooth_sand_tiger.distribution: It is a deep-sea shark, reported punctually throughout the world. It is found, for example, in Colombian waters off the island of Malpelo. At a certain time of the year, it can sometimes be observed because it rises at shallower depths when the surface waters are cold (due to the Humboldt current).

bluntnose_sixgill_shark.name: Bluntnose sixgill shark
bluntnose_sixgill_shark.description: The bluntnose shark is a massive shark, with a large rounded or pointed head. It has 6 pairs of gill slits and a single dorsal fin at the back of the body, characters often described as primitive in the literature, as well as small, fluorescent green, retractable eyes. The mouth is placed on the ventral side and contains 6 rows of comb-like teeth. The tail is short and stubby. He only sees in monochrome.
bluntnose_sixgill_shark.distribution: The bluntnose shark is one of the most widely distributed sharks in the world since it is present in the temperate or tropical seas of the Eastern and Western Atlantic, the Western, Central and Eastern Pacific, as well as in the Mediterranean Sea, well that its populations are never very abundant in the observation areas.

salmon_shark.name: Salmon shark
salmon_shark.description: The salmon shark or porbeagle shark (Lamna ditropis) is a species of shark in the family Lamnidae. It is a predator of the salmon from which it takes its name. It can reach 3 meters in length, it is able to swim at more than 50km/h. The salmon shark has the ability to withstand very cold temperatures like those in Alaska where, in winter, the water temperature varies between 2 and 8°C. This faculty results from a specific vascular system.
salmon_shark.distribution: It lives in the North Pacific Ocean, especially in Alaska, but can migrate to subtropical areas, a tagging study having shown that it could go down to Hawaii and travel more than 18,000 km in 640 days. Females are more common along the Alaskan coast, while males are concentrated on the Siberian side. It is found from the surface to 650 meters deep.
